indicators.justification:
Together with other EaP countries, Azerbaijan joined the initiative of Basic indicators of the joint system of ecological information (1). This initiative is funded by the EU and supported by European Environment Agency. The Statistics Committee publishes basic environmental data based on the EU methodology (2). The Ministry of Environment and Natural Resources has created a web portal for biodiversity (3). The portal covers almost all aspects of biodiversity as text. There is no downloadable data in the portal. As part of this portal, there are red and green book sub-sections (4). The Redbook part of the portal classifies the biodiversity based on the methodology of the International Union for Conservation of Nature. However, there are a lot of technical challenges on the page. The search tool and many sections do not work. Several fields do not have information.

(2) https://www.stat.gov.az/source/environment/
(3) https://biodiversity.az/az
(4) http://redbook.biodiversity.az/index.php

indicators.justification:
The law on state registration and state register of legal entities (12.12.2003 № 224-IIQ560-IIQ) regulate the state registration of the legal entities. It covers the name, surname, patronymic, citizenship, and place of residence of each founder of the legal entity (1). In the case of the founder is a legal entity, information on its name, legal address, and registration are specified in the law as a subject for information collection. If the founder is a state or municipality the government or municipality specified is subjected to provide information about the legal entity in Article 5.3.2-1 of this Law (article 14.1.6.).
State register is open only for a single case and with a unique number search option. The exception is the information on the founders (participants) of commercial legal entities and their shares in the authorized capital. Each person has the right to acquire the entries to the state register, request an extract from the state register, and copies of documents submitted for registration. The relevant executive authority of the Republic of Azerbaijan must provide information on the state registration or removal of the registration of a legal entity at the request of an interested person (Article 18.1.) (1)
According to the law on Commercial secrets (12.04.2001 № 224-IIQ ), information about the founders (participants) of commercial legal entities and their shares in the authorized capital is considered as commercial secret and is not publicly available (Article 4.1.2) (2) (3).

The law On state registration and state register of legal entities regulates that Information on the founders (participants) of commercial legal entities and their shares in the authorized capital is provided upon request of heirs of the founders (participants), Court, advocate, compulsory executive body, etc. (article 15.9) (2) (3)
In summary, the legal framework does not include specific regulations for natural persons who have ownership or control share in a registered company. All founder's or participants information stipulated in the law On state registration and state register of legal entities are not available online as required by law.  

Sources
Links accessed in 20-27 July 2021

(1)	Law On state registration and state register of legal entities: http://e-qanun.az/framework/5403
(2) Law on trade secrets http://e-qanun.az/framework/2861 
(3) http://old.taxes.gov.az/modul.php?name=pages&page=20&lang=

indicators.justification:
The statistics office shares information about civil registration and vital statistics. It does not comply with the methodology of WHO, nevertheless, the coverage is relatively close. The dataset published by the Statistics Information Service has information about death, birth, natural population increase, the death of children less than one-year-old, mothers' age during the birth, mother's death, children with - less than 5 years old (1). The Statistics Committee also publishes annual statistics about the main reasons for deaths, main indicators of healthcare, doctors' professions, disease statistics by age and gender, treatment and prevention services for the population (2). Data are published annually (last time in 2019).

The official websites of The State Agency on Mandatory Health Insurance (3), The Ministry of Healthcare (4), and The Public Health and Reform Center under the Ministry of Healthcare (5) were reviewed. None of them has significant statistical data.

Source

(2) https://www.stat.gov.az/source/healthcare/
(3) https://its.gov.az/
(4) http://www.sehiyye.gov.az/
(5) https://isim.az/en

indicators.justification:
With the support of the World Bank, the Azerbaijan Government and State Service on Property Issues under the Ministry of Economy had a project – Registration of Property. "Real Estate Registration, Cadaster, and Management System" collects all detailed information about the land ownership and position them on a high-quality map. According to the official information of the State Service on Property, this information system works and collects information constantly (1). 
This project supports several e-gov services that citizens can use. From the perspective of land data collection and use, Checking registry information, Providing additional information about the real estate (2) services that exist in the electronic service portal. However, such services provide information with unique identifiers and for a single case. 
In summary, land tenure information does exist in State Service on Property Issues. Nevertheless, it is not publicly available.

indicators.justification:
There are two main sources for public financial information: The State Statistical Committee and The Ministry of Finance. Both sources do not provide detailed information about public finance. Generalized information does exist in both sources. The ministry provides monthly reports in PDF format (1) (2). General report on execution of the state budget does exist in PDF with relatively better details. The PDF files have tabular data, unfortunately, the Ministry does not publish it in any tabular data format (3). The ministry informs that it is possible to get such information in an Excel file with an information request (maliyye.gov.az/site/write-letter). But, the procedure is to publish them as PDF.

Basic information about the state debt exists only in text format (4).

indicators.justification:
The law on political parties requires that financial annual statements should be given to the  Central Election Commission. It is possible to find mentioned information on the website of the commission (1). 
According to the Regulation on approval of the "Form, content and Rules for submission of financial statements of political parties," the financial statements of the political parties should contain information about the donor's last name, first name, patronymic, address, series, number of the identity card or the document substituting it, and the amount of the donation (Article 4.3.2) (2012.16 11 No263) (2). However, this regulation does not work properly in the practice. The source (website) clearly depicts that the data is not submitted as regulation requires.  

Sources

(1) http://www.msk.gov.az/uploads/partiyalar/2019/MaliyyeHesabatlari.php

indicators.justification:
According to the law on public procurement, the government creates a single Internet portal of public procurement. The portal publishes invitations on procurement procedures and results of these procedures, maintains a single register of procurement contracts and invalid contractors, by electronic means of public procurement a single internet portal that ensures its implementation, reflects the legislation regulating public procurement and is integrated into the electronic information system of the body (institution) determined by the relevant executive authority  (Article 1) (27.12. 2001 № 245-IIQ) (1) (2).
The portal does not allow to download of bulk data in a machine-readable format, all information is on the page without a download option. Web scraping is possible, but this is not a friendly option.
As mentioned in the law approximately all information relating to the procurement is stipulated in the tender portal. The portal includes goods and services, public works, planning phase, tender stage, and award stage information. In addition, according to the law, all public sector bodies must publish the above-mentioned information in the portal. Even they carry administrative responsibility. (Article of Administrative Code 445-1) (3) (2)   
The contract implementation stage 
According to the law on Public procurement relations between the parties signing the procurement contract is regulated by this Law, the Civil Code of the Republic of Azerbaijan, and other normative legal acts. Civil Code does not require any information sharing related to the implementation of any contract, including procurement contracts as well. 
The portal has a user-friendly search system to find necessary information relating to a single procurement process (2).
The e-tender portal has a section about signed contracts where possible to find the name and taxpayer identification number of the awarded company. Such information allows finding more details about the legal representative and legal address of the company from the online tax system.
As the portal shows all tenders start from the announcement of tender and end with the signing of the contract or cancellation of the tender. Each signed contract includes the name of the purchasing organization, Name of the awarded company, taxpayer identification number, name of goods (works/services), and name of tender, purchase amount, date of publication, Start, and Expiration date (5). The portal has information related to the document names. However, documents themselves are not available (4). To access the documents, participants should pay fees.
The portal has a separate search function to find relevant information in the portal and among the listed procurements. In addition, the general structure of the portal is user-friendly.
Timeliness
According to the law on Public procurement, all tender announcements and results of tenders should be in the portal. That is why all information in the portal is up to date. For example, the last agreement on the portal is the agreement signed today (22 July 2021). Or the last cancellation date of tender is yesterday.
The portal was launched per the presidential decree (6) (16/04/2019     № 647). The historical data at the portal is from 2018, the old tender information has not been migrated to the portal. The contract implementation information is not available at the portal or in any other resources.

indicators.justification:
In 2014, the Ministry of Communication and High Tech initiated a data portal (1)for sharing public data. Although it was slow, there were few datasets published. Starting from 2014, there were several events and competitions were organized for increasing data utilization (2). 
However, all initiatives are episodic and do not have solid regulatory support. A recent National Action Plan for the Promotion of Open Government 2020-2022 highlights a task for all government agencies to develop an open data section on their website. Furthermore, the National Action plan targets to adopt open data standards by 2022. So far, there is no progress in the implementation. The National Open Data Portal maintained by the Ministry of Transport, Communication and High Tech publishes several open data. Conceptually, the portal covers API services, documentation, code samples, etc. However, in practice, all the published data (or API services) are imitative and lack useful data sources. Many of the published open data have not been updated. Almost 80% of datasets were published on either 18 December 2020 or 6 October 2017. Datasets are not important, but mostly informative such as basic location information of mountains, rivers, forests, national parks, seed sellers, customs calculator, postal service fees and etc. 

Few hackathons were organized by public organizations, nevertheless, they have not targeted the usage of open data. The portal also lists several applications built by using open data such as exchange rates, switching SIM cards, locations of post offices, etc. Again, those cannot be considered a promotion of the open data concept.

Other than the national open data portal, The Ministry of Agriculture developed a data portal and publishes open data related to agriculture. The portal has a data visualization opening that presents general statistical information (3). This portal publishes several interesting agriculture-related data and provides basic data analysis capabilities. 

Summary:
The "National Action Plan for the Promotion of Open Government for 2020-2022" was adopted. One of the main goals of the plan is to increase transparency and make an important contribution to ensuring access to information. Building a better open data ecosystem with data standards is also covered in the action plan. We can expect that open data initiatives will be enhanced in the coming years. So far, the Open data field is in the early stages of its development.

Sources
Links accessed on 1 - 20 July 2021

(2) https://www.e-gov.az/az/news/read/620
(3) https://agrodata.az/az/

indicators.justification:
A legal framework for Data sharing and open data does not exist. However, there are several regulatory documents that discuss the accessibility of information for disabled citizens. 
Although the country has joined the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, there is no practice of using special means, tools and software to ensure access to information for citizens with disabilities. Based on the requirements of the Convention, a decision was made to facilitate the use of state information resources by citizens with disabilities. That is why, a Resolution of the Cabinet of Ministers (No. 189 of September 4, 2012) was adopted. According to the resolution on Requirements for the creation and management of Internet information resources of government agencies, there are several requirements for maintaining the access of disabled citizens to public information. In order for people with disabilities to effectively access and use information resources, access to Internet information resources must be provided in accordance with the international standard WCAG (Web Content Accessibility Guideline) 2.1 (Web Content Accessibility Guide).
-	text alternatives for non-textual content, transcripts for audio and video content, subtitles, use of large fonts, font selection, colour management, character spacing should be provided;
-	the creation of a time management function, providing users with sufficient time to read and use the content, the ability to control processes from the keyboard, the function of deactivating animated images, the content must be clear and consistent;
-	readable and understandable language (style) should be used;(part 11)(2)
It should be noted that in accordance with the requirements of Part 8 of the Rules, each state body is responsible for the fulfilment of the responsibilities. (2)
Conclusion
The above rules apply to all government agencies. It should be noted that this requirement for people with disabilities is set in the rules of the Cabinet of Ministers from 2020, so the required software or add-ins to the official websites of government agencies have not been implemented yet. Some sites meet the font, colour and other requirements relating to disabled people (3). 


(1)	On the rights of persons with disabilities Convention https://www.justice.gov.az/categories/115 
(2)	Resolution of the Cabinet of Ministers of the Republic of "On approval of the" Requirements for the creation and management of Internet information resources of government agencies" 4.09.2012 № 189 http://www.e-qanun.az/framework/24256 
(3)	Official webpage of The Ministry of Labor and Social Protection
https://www.sosial.gov.az/

indicators.justification:
Personal Data Law of Azerbaijan Republic (11 May 2010, 998-IIIQ), section 7.1.1 indicates that everyone has a right to get information on the availability of personal information about him(her)self from the owner or operator of the information system that collects personal data. Section 8.1. indicates that, the collection and processing of personal data about any person are allowed only with written consent, or in the form of an electronic document with the electronic signature of a person. The only exception is for cases of compulsory collection and processing of personal data in the manner prescribed by the legislation of the Azerbaijan Republic.
Section 7.1. of the Law (- Receiving information about their personal data; - Receiving information about the intention of the personal data collection; - Requesting to correct or delete personal data).
Article 12 (a person can request information about his/her personal data. Data collectors should provide complete information, free of charge, within 7 days (in case of urgent need, it can be extended 7 days).
According to the Law, those that collect personal data should create a security system that prevents unintentional use of personal data. In case of a personal data breach, the personal data collector should compensate the data owner for damage, and its amount is determined by the court.
The Law does not cover explicitly the types of data and actions depending on the types of data.
General conclusion:
Personal Data Law of Azerbaijan Republic (11 May 2010, 998-IIIQ) provides a comprehensive framework to protect and regulate personal data collection, usage, and removal.  The adoption of the Law is related to the approval of the Convention for the Protection of Individuals with regard to Automatic Processing of Personal Data (ETS No.108) by the Azerbaijan Republic.
Personal data information systems must be registered with the Ministry of Transport, Communications, and High Technologies. All personal data collectors are listed on the website of the Registry (5).

indicators.justification:
According to the Constitution, the official language of the Republic of Azerbaijan is the Azerbaijani language. All official information should be presented in this language. Moreover, the law on national language regulates the requirement. (30.09. 2002№ 365-IIQ) (1). The law does not restrict legal entities from collecting and disseminating information in other languages. For this reason, many websites of official bodies are available in both official and foreign languages. 

The law on information, informatization and information protection requires that the owner of the Internet information resource is independent in determining the content of the information placed in that information resource and the procedure for its placement. The owner of the Internet information resource and its domain name must ensure the lawful operation of that information resource, including compliance with the norms of the state language, and is personally responsible for it. (Article 13-2.1.) (3.04.1998 № 460-IQ) (2)

However, none of the mentioned regulatory documents discusses sharing data and its language requirements.

indicators.justification:
The openness of information comes from the requirement of the Constitution. The constitution necessitates that everyone has the right to seek, receive, transmit, prepare and disseminate information legally. Everyone is guaranteed the right to refute or respond to information published in the media that violates his rights or interests.

Moreover, several laws and other legal acts regulate issues about information dissemination and its aspects.  In general, the legal framework for information sharing is significantly broad. At the same time, the issue is regulated by normative acts of the highest legal force (1) (2) (3).
Open data, on the other hand, has not been evolved much in Azerbaijan. The abovementioned legal acts define mostly information sharing and do not highlight open data per see.

The Law about information, informatization, and information protection stipulates that Open information - documented information, the acquisition, processing, transfer or use of which is not limited by the legislation of the Republic of Azerbaijan and is intended for general use(4).
The Law on getting information notes that public information is facts, opinions, information created or obtained in the process of fulfillment of public duties defined by-laws or other normative legal acts. However, such information should not necessarily be published as tabular data.

The same law defines the openness of information - dissemination of information in mass media, official publications, questionnaires, or information booklets without request, placement in Internet information resources, announcement at briefings, press releases or conferences, announcement at official or mass events.(5)
In sum, the given definitions do not directly describe the open data concept but create possibilities to share information in machine-readable formats.

In general, the legal framework covers the freedom of information concept, not the open data framework. Publishing public information as open data is not covered explicitly in any of the mentioned legal acts.

indicators.justification:
The legal framework of public finance and the publication of the information related to them are regulated with two core legal acts: Law on Budget system (1), Law on Chamber of accounts (3), and Law on getting information (2). 
According to the Law on Budget system, the draft law on the state budget for the next budget year shall be published in the press within 10 days from the date of its submission to the Parliament of the Republic of Azerbaijan together with the documents specified in Articles 12.1.1 - 12.1.10 (this document includes income, debt, budget, spending, and other public financial information, etc.) of this Law.  (Article 14) (16.12.2016 No462-VQD) (1)
The quarterly report on the execution of the state budget shall be published in the media (Article 20.2) (16.12.2016 No462-VQD) (1). Following this rule, The Ministry of Finance publishes monthly reports.
According to the Freedom of Information Law, the owner of public finance information (state bodies, state-owned companies, etc.) should disclose budget forecasts, reports on the execution of the state budget, and consolidated budget (Article 29) (30.09.2005 № 1024-IIQ) (2). There is no common practice for fulfilling these requirements. Some public organizations, including the Ministry of Finance, systematically open public finance information. The law does not specify if such information should be machine-readable or not. Therefore, it is common that organizations to publish PDF files rather than machine-readable format.
The Cabinet of Ministers' Regulation on 'Information on the annual financial activities of budget organizations, public legal entities established on behalf of the state, extra-budgetary state funds, 30 percent or more of shares (shares) owned by the state, as well as the use of funds provided from the state budget or property allocated to them Rules for Disclosure of Information in Internet Information Resources'  regulates forms off disclosed information.  According to this rule, reports should be published no later than April 30 of the following year (6.11.2018 No504) (4) 
Conclusion
For all public finance, the public entities should disclose financial reports on their web pages. Common practice is to publish basic financial information as a PDF file. There is no source for detailed budget and spending information.

indicators.justification:
The Law on political parties, which is the primary regulatory framework, demands that Political parties should publish their annual financial statements in the media together with the auditor's report (Article 21.5) (03.06. 1992 № 147) (1). The law discusses "information" disclosure, there is no obligation for the parties to open information as open data. All published information is in PDF format (scanned image).
Annual financial reports of political parties are posted on the official website of the Central Election Commission of the Republic of Azerbaijan (2) (Article 21.6) (03.06. 1992 № 147).
According to the Law on political parties, the maximum amount of donations a person can make to one or more parties during the year may not exceed ten thousand manats (Article 19.7).

In conclusion, the regulations and legal framework give a sufficient overview of political party accountability in terms of financial activities. Nevertheless, in practice, such accountability is formal and does not cover the details of financial resource usage. We can see it from the published reports. For example, the leading party, The New Azerbaijan Party, published one page PDF financial report (4). The Party presents the costs with general statements like "funds spent on current works". Such descriptions do not allow a citizen to understand precisely what was the current works. This is applicable for other reports as well.

indicators.justification:
The web portal of the Public Counsel which is the main organizer publishes detailed information on the website. Nevertheless, the published information is not machine-readable and that is why it is impossible to analyze data and progress (2).
The law on Legal normative acts requires that by the decision of the regulation development body, the draft normative legal act may be put up for open (public or professional) discussion (Article 9.2) ( 21.12.2010 № 21-IVKQ) (7). The data collection related to the consultations is not regulated by the law. In addition, it is possible to see that it is not an imperative norm to put legal acts to the open discussion. 
Nearly all state bodies have their Public Counsels. Most of the members of public consult are from non-governmental organizations. Additionally, it is possible to find sufficient information relating to their activity (3)  (4) (5) (8).
Conclusion
Although many pieces of legislation allow or define the framework for public participation, it is difficult to find information about the discussions covering critical and highly debated subjects. The results of discussions, the proposal development process, etc. are not systematically published and accessible in a user-friendly manner.

indicators.justification:
The law on getting information requires that Disclosing of information is the dissemination of information in mass media, official publications, questionnaires or information booklets, placement in Internet information resources, announcement at briefings, press releases or conferences, announcement at official or mass events without request. In addition, disclosing public information is an obligation of state bodies, municipalities, legal entities performing public functions (including public legal entities), companies occupying a dominant position in the market, etc.  (Article 3.0.8 and 9) (30.09. 2005 № 1024-IIQ) (1).
According to the law, information owners should publish 34 types of information, in order to decrease the number of information requests (Article 29) (1).
There is no direct statement that highlights the collection and publication of data regarding the number of requests submitted and processed. 
The RTI Framework regulates that the request for information shall be executed as soon as possible, but no later than 7 working days. However, there is no direct regulation about data collection and publication of data regarding how long it took the relevant government agency or agencies to fill requests.  (Article 24.1)
Conclusion
Although the right to information is sufficiently regulated by law, the law does not regulate the information on the status of inquiries. The above-mentioned law regulates information that must be disclosed without a request, investigation of information requests, refusal to respond to a request, and other points. But the regulation of the follow-up of the information requests is not regulated according to the same law, (such as disclosing information about the number of requests submitted; response times for filling requests; denials and reasons for withholding etc.)

indicators.justification:
As public procurement data is not downloadable, it has not been used for analytical or service creation purposes. There is no data related to procurement in the official open data portal of Azerbaijan (opendata.az). Startup communities and activists had organized a few competitions and hackathons in the last few years. However, none of them were used procurement data (1) (2) (3). There are several articles and journalist research about illegal tender procedures in the local media (4) (5) (6). None of them uses procurement data systematically.  Nevertheless, the e-tender portal helps journalists to retrieve some information about a particular procurement case (7).
